Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Chilean Coastal Orographic Precipitation Experiment pilot project (CCOPE-2015)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract
A team of investigators, working with colleagues in Chile, will undertake a multi-month (May-August, 2015) deployment to the Nahuelbuta Mountains of Southern Chile to measure orographic induced precipitation during the southern hemisphere wet season. This geographic location will allow the investigators to test the generality of existing theories of coastal orographic precipitation in comparison with similar mountains along the Coastal Range of California. This research will lead to potential new discoveries of coastal precipitation patterns along the southern South America coastline.

Intellectual Merit
The geographic location of the Nahuelbuta Mountains of southern Chile provides a unique location to study the role of aerosols and small-scale motions in orographic precipitation. Details of precipitation processes have not been examined for coastal South America. As such, data collected during this field experiment will serve as a critical test of existing theories or coastal orographic precipitation and compared with well-studied areas such as the coastal mountain ranges of California. Simultaneous vertical measurements of thermodynamic properties, aerosol distributions, rainfall size distributions, and radar profiles will aid in the characterization of relationships between precipitation, aerosol loading, and small scale convective motions.

Broader Impacts
Two graduate students will gain invaluable experience in field measurements of precipitation. Additionally, this team will work with Chilean researchers and will educate local secondary school children from Chile on the outcomes of these experiments. This research will result in observational datasets from an area of the world largely under-served by modern instrumentation. These data will be used in the evaluation of numerical models and testing of quantitative precipitation estimation algorithms based on remote sensing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant funded the University at Albany (UAlbany) contribution to data collection and analysis associated with the exploratory 2015 Chilean Coastal Orographic Precipitation Experiment (CCOPE-2015). The scientific goals of this project centered on collecting measurements from Nahuelbuta Mountains of coastal Chile (38 deg. S) during austral winter 2015 to better understand the processes that affect rainfall over coastal mountain ranges. Understanding such processes is important because coastal terrain can strongly influence the intensity and distribution of rainfall in ways that are not fully understood. Rainfall over such mountains can have important impacts on hazards (flooding, landslides) and resources (ecosystems, water supply).

 

The primary field observations of CCOPE-2015 took place during May-August of 2015. Instrumentation was deployed to measure: surface weather conditions, rainfall accumulation, vertical variations of weather conditions through the lower atmosphere, as well as rain drop and aerosol size and number concentrations. The UAlbany research group worked with collaborators to define the experimental design and deployment/operation strategy.  A graduate student funded under UAlbany support was responsible for oversight and support of all field operations. Additionally, he was the primary researcher in charge of radar and weather balloon observations.

 

A major focus of scientific analysis by the UAlbany research group has been understanding how variations in precipitation (rain and snow) growth processes above the Earth’s surface affect the amount of rain that falls over coastal mountains. In particular, we focused on comparing periods, or “regimes”, when rainfall is initiated as snow and ice high in the atmosphere with periods when it originates from entirely liquid clouds. Most previous work examining such rainfall processes over coastal mountains was based on observations from coastal California in North America.  The results of our work have built on those observations, showing many of the conclusions drawn from California also apply in coastal Chile, despite contrasts in geography and likely contrasts in atmospheric aerosol loading. We have also added new detail to the understanding of coastal mountain rainfall by characterizing atmospheric conditions upwind of the mountains and detailed measurements of mountain rainfall enhancement across rainfall regimes.

 

 Overall, these results provide a sharper picture of mountain precipitation processes in coastal environments. The main results from the UAlbany research groups’ efforts have been presented at several scientific conferences and in one published scientific journal article (https://journals.ametsoc.org/doi/full/10.1175/JHM-D-17-0005.1). Furthermore, the data collected as part of the UAlbany efforts has been organized into a publically available web-accessible archive for use by other researchers  (https://www.eol.ucar.edu/field_projects/CCOPE-2015/).

 

Broader impacts of this project extend beyond the above scientific results.  Project funding supported one year of training of a graduate student who gained experience in field observations and completed a Master of Science degree, writing a thesis based on CCOPE-2015 research. During the field phase of the project, scientific outreach presentations were made at a local Chilean secondary school. Students were able to participate in the launching of a weather balloon. Data collected during CCOPE-2015 is currently being used for evaluation of computer models that are used for weather forecasting in an effort to better characterize model strengths and weaknesses in order to improve forecasts of high-impact weather events. CCOPE-2015 data are also being used to evaluate estimates of rainfall made be satellites, which may improve warnings for dangerous flood and landslide events.
